verses.text: During Jehoiakim’s reign, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came, and Jehoiakim became his servant for three years. Then he turned and rebelled against him.
verses.comment: Follows the Masoretic text. 'Servant' here means vassal king.

verses.text: And the LORD sent against Jehoiakim bands of Chaldeans, Arameans, Moabites, and Ammonites. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the LORD that He spoke through His servants the prophets.
verses.comment: Retains the sequence of invading groups as per Hebrew text.

verses.text: Surely this came upon Judah by the command of the LORD, to remove them from His sight, because of all the sins of Manasseh, according to all that he had done.
verses.comment: ‘Remove from His sight’ is literal; includes the causal reference.

verses.text: And also for the innocent blood that he had shed; for he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the LORD would not forgive.
verses.comment: ‘Would not forgive’ echoes the finality of God’s judgment.

verses.text: The rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Follows the formulaic language for historical records.

verses.text: So Jehoiakim slept with his fathers, and Jehoiachin his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' is retained for traditional phrasing.

verses.text: And the king of Egypt did not come out of his land anymore, for the king of Babylon had taken all that belonged to the king of Egypt from the Brook of Egypt to the Euphrates River.
verses.comment: 'Brook of Egypt' left literal; this refers to Egypt’s loss of influence.

verses.text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he began to reign, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Nehushta, the daughter of Elnathan from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Age aligns with most Hebrew manuscripts; some differ (see Chronicles).

verses.text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, according to all that his father had done.
verses.comment: Maintains parallel phrasing from Kings and Chronicles.

verses.text: At that time, the servants of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up to Jerusalem, and the city was besieged.
verses.comment: Straightforward rendering of siege event.

verses.text: And Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came to the city while his servants were besieging it.
verses.comment: Simple recounting of Nebuchadnezzar’s arrival.

verses.text: Then Jehoiachin king of Judah, along with his mother, his servants, his officials, and his eunuchs, surrendered to the king of Babylon. And in the eighth year of his reign, the king of Babylon took him prisoner.
verses.comment: ‘Eunuchs’ used as per original; ‘surrendered’ clarifies ‘went out.’

verses.text: And he carried out all the treasures of the house of the LORD, and the treasures of the king’s house. He cut in pieces all the gold vessels which Solomon king of Israel had made in the temple of the LORD, as the LORD had foretold.
verses.comment: Divides gold vessels ‘cut in pieces’ as literal per text.

verses.text: And he carried away all Jerusalem, all the officials, all the mighty men of valor, ten thousand captives, and all the craftsmen and smiths. None remained except the poorest people of the land.
verses.comment: Retains separate classes as listed; 'craftsmen and smiths' kept literal.

verses.text: He carried away Jehoiachin to Babylon along with the king’s mother, the king’s wives, his officials, and the leading men of the land. He took them into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon.
verses.comment: ‘Into exile’ clarifies forced migration.

verses.text: All the men of valor, seven thousand, and the craftsmen and smiths, one thousand—all strong and fit for war—the king of Babylon brought captive to Babylon.
verses.comment: Numerical details maintained as per text.

verses.text: And the king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin’s uncle, king in his place and changed his name to Zedekiah.
verses.comment: ‘Changed his name’ is literal; Mattaniah = Zedekiah.

verses.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
verses.comment: Details kept as per narrative.

verses.text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, just as Jehoiakim had done.
verses.comment: Parallels prior kings’ repeated sinfulness.

verses.text: For because of the anger of the LORD, this happened to Jerusalem and Judah, until He cast them out from His presence. And Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
verses.comment: 'Cast them out from His presence' preserves literal phrasing.
